title: 107_hr14
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform Act of 2001". The Congress acknowledges the projected depletion of the Social Security trust funds by 2037 due to demographic factors like the aging population and fewer workers supporting the system. Policymakers may need to raise taxes, cut spending, or borrow money to address this issue, as public confidence in Social Security's long-term sustainability is low. The need for Social Security reform is evident due to the projected depletion of trust funds by 2037. Despite public concerns about its long-term sustainability, there is no consensus on how to address the issue, as reflected in various proposals and bills introduced in Congress. This lack of agreement has led to a standstill in Social Security reform efforts. The need for Social Security reform is evident due to the projected depletion of trust funds by 2037. Despite differences within Congress and the administration, there has been no movement on Social Security reform. To address this, a Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform will be established to develop a unified proposal for long-term retirement security. The Bipartisan Commission on Social Security Reform will design recommendations for restoring the system's solvency and maintaining retirement income security in the United States. The Commission on Social Security Reform consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders, with the Commissioner of Social Security as a nonvoting member. Members must be individuals of recognized standing and distinction. Members must be individuals of recognized standing and distinction, representing multiple generations with a stake in the Social Security system. Appointments should include individuals representing the interests of employees and employers. The Chair of the Commission is designated by officials and supervises its duties and staff. Members are appointed within 30 days of the enactment of this legislation. The Co-Chairs of the Commission determine its duties, supervise its staff, and fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 6. PROCEDURES.

The Commission shall meet at the call of its Chair or a majority of its members. Once 9 or more members are appointed, they can select the Chair who will lead the Commission's operations. A quorum consists of nine members, but a smaller number can conduct hearings. The Commission may hold hearings and gather necessary information from government agencies.

SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION. The Commission members do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits, except for travel expenses and per diem. The Chair appoints a staff director who is compensated according to specified rates. Staff members are appointed based on agreed-upon rules. The Commission appoints additional staff as needed, who are exempt from civil service laws and paid without regard to General Schedule rates. The staff director can hire temporary services with Commission approval. The Architect of the Capitol provides office space for the Commission's operation. The Architect of the Capitol provides suitable office space and necessary equipment for the Commission's headquarters. The Commission can request administrative support services from various entities on a nonreimbursable basis. Additionally, departments and agencies of the United States may provide further support services as authorized by law. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails for communication. The Commission may receive services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as needed and authorized by law. It can use the United States mails and is considered a commission of Congress for printing purposes. The Commission will submit a report to the House of Representatives and Senate within 6 months of its first meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The report must be approved by at least nine members. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. Funds necessary for the Commission's activities are authorized to be appropriated, with $2,000,000 available until specific funds are allocated.
